Input.threadtitle: Lecture 7e: are the read/write/keep gates also trained w/backpropagation algorithm?
Input.posts:
In lecture 7e it is explained how the backpropagation algorithm works for RNNs with memory cells. I understand that the propagation can be done through the memory cells, since the gates provide weights to the connections to and from them. But I was wondering how the read, write and keep gates themselves are trained. Obviously, the way the cells are steered has a great impact on the net performance. Is it somehow possible to include this in the framework of backpropagation or do you need a separate strategy to train the gates? Or is this simply part of the net design?
Upvotes:
7
I wanted to know that too. Do you just set up some random read/write/keep gates in your network and hope that the right information will be stuck in them when you train?
Upvotes:
2

Instructor's Post
It's all trained together with gradient descent (backpropagation). Every parameter, including those of the forget gates, has an effect on the final output and the loss, so we can compute those derivatives and adjust the weights in the usual way.

Input.threadtitle: Lecture 9: weight constraints
Input.posts:
Hi all, I am curious on how to implement the weight contraints during the optimization routine. I am speaking about the constraint on the maximum length of an incoming weight vector to a unit. If anyone has more information on how to implement this, it would be very much appreciated. Will
Upvotes:
2
One obvious method is to use softmax ;) Its output is automatically normalized. Another method is to parametrises the last weight in terms of previous $$n-1$$. The third method is to minimise the lagrangian instead of the original function -- $$F(x) + \lambda*(x_1+\ldots +x_n - 1)$$. [Edit:] This is of course for linear constraints only.
Upvotes:
0
But isn't that an equality constraint. I thought that, in the lecture, an inequality '$$\leq$$' contraint is implied.
Upvotes:
0
ahh ... right the entire course till that point was about linear constraints, so I got a bit confused.
Upvotes:
0
In the lecture, it was said that you rescale if the weight vector is too long. So, test for whether the updated length of the weight vector is greater than the constraint. If so, rescale it by the constraint divided by the length. You could try to use a linear approximation of this: In case you start on or beyond the constraint, project the change in the weight vector to a component orthogonal to the constraints. However, this would allow you to overshoot the constraint, and if you start on the constraint you could slowly move beyond it with second-order effects.

Input.threadtitle: Why hasn't Hessian Free optimization made obsolete all Gradient Descent methods?
Input.posts:
Apparently the HF optimizer is all advantages over the GD methods (2º order so much faster, no learning rate, able to cope with vanishing gradients...), so why are the latter still used at all? What are the disadvantages of HF?
Upvotes:
4
The fact that Conjugate Gradient takes fewer steps to reach convergence does not mean that it is always faster than other methods. In fact, calculating the exact step size of each step in CG is somewhat costly and other methods can still be faster when making good approximations of the inverse Hessian (cf. L-BFGS for example). Note also that error surfaces are not always quadratic, so you typically need to calculate a quadratic approximations of your error surface before using standard CG. I am not an expert in this area but I would guess that a separate course on statistical ML would help to understand, when each of the two sets of methods work better/faster.
Upvotes:
3
Oh, and by the way, if your problem is convex, there will be no need to calculate the Hessian matrix (or any approximation of it) in the first place. So basic gradient methods will always be (computationally) much simpler than CG in those cases. Remember that we are only interested in more complex methods because of potential 'twists' in the error surface. Such twists do not occur if your error function is linear, for example, as in the case of linear regression or similar methods.

I believe this is correct. As I cannot think of much other functionality comes from the recurrent nature. The way I see it is like this: Normal feed-forward networks have no sense of 'time', unless your data input is a time based representation - I'll get to the differences in a bit. In recurrent networks, when you update the network to the next 'step', I like to think of it as a time 'step'. As the inputs change over time, the network sees these changes in a certain order at a certain time 'step'. This allows the network to respond not only to the current inputs, but because of the recurrent connections - specifically ones that do not go 'forward' towards the output layer, we are able to retain some of the 'information' from previous inputs. I believe the power of recurrent networks is not so much just 'memory' or memory over time, but how it can achieve this. This goes back to my first statement that a normal feed-forward network can still model/predict things over 'time' if you provide it inputs over 'time'. But this type of network is limited to how much 'memory' it can 'see' based on how you format the input. In a recurrent network, it could potentially 'remember' information from the very first input sequence. The recurrent connections, and actually the weights themselves ( and much more complex inter-weight/node reactions/flows ), control how much 'memory' is 'remembered'. This makes them much more powerful, because the network itself can be trained to 'remember' as much or as little of the information from the time-sequence inputs as the training dictates. Back to your original question. I cannot actually see a good use for recurrent neural networks off the top of my head that has a use, or clear advantage, over 'regular' tasks which do not involve long timelines. I think long timelines is exactly what they are good for. If there are short time lines, then as I stated above, they could probably be implemented with a regular feed-forward net. Maybe another way to approach this problem is with some 'specs'. I think a recurrent neural network might have less calculations in certain situations. If only a few characteristic features from a timeline of inputs is required for the solution, then there might be less calculations required. For example, a prediction on a time sequence that only had a direct relationship to the very first input in the sequence might be more suitable for a recurrent network because a feed forward network that had all of the inputs would probably weight the rest of the inputs very low and thus have not much affect on the output. Potentially a much smaller, simpler recurrent network might have less calculations to deal with? This is all starting to get into theory and conjecture that isn't backed up with any math - I'm just postulating what may be the case, and maybe opening up some discussion by giving some viewpoints to think about.
